facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1956 appealed by special leave from Orissa High Court judgment dated April 12, 1955 in O.J.C. No. 60 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 12, 1955, of the Orissa High Court in 0. J. C. No. 60 of 1952.

facts.text: Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Orissa XIV of 1947) received assent of Governor-General on April 26, 1947, section 1 came into force then.

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947  Orissa XIV of 1947 , hereinafter referred to as the said Act received the assent of the Governor-General on April 26, 1947, when s. I of the Act came into force.

facts.text: Notification issued August 1, 1947 by Government of Orissa bringing rest of the Act into force in Province of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1947, a Notification was issued by the Government of Orissa bringing the rest of the said Act into force in the Province of Orissa, as it was then companystituted.

facts.text: Notification August 14, 1947 appointing September 30, 1947 as date for s.4(1) to come into force.

anchor.surface_text: On August 14, 1947, a numberification was issued by the Government of Orissa appointing September 30, 1947, as the date with effect from which that sub-section was to companye into force

facts.text: Feudatory State of Pallahara merged into province of Orissa on January 1, 1948 by covenant of merger.

anchor.surface_text: On January 1, 1948, by a companyenant of merger executed by its ruler, the feudatory State of Pallahara merged into the province of Orissa.

facts.text: Government of Orissa issued notification December 14, 1948 under Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act extending Orissa Sales Tax Act to erstwhile feudatory states including Pallahara.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers delegated to it by the Government of India under what was then known as the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947, the Government of Orissa on December 14, 1948, issued a numberification

facts.text: Notification March 1, 1949 under s.1(3) bringing ss.2 to 29 into force in added territories.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1, 1949, a numberification under s. 1  3  was issued by the Government of Orissa bringing ss. 2 to 29 of the said Act into force in the added territories.

facts.text: Notification March 1, 1949 under s.4(1) appointing 31st March 1949 as date, but referring to year ending 31st March 1949 for turnover exceeding Rs.5000.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day another numberification was issued under s. 4 1  of the Act, which was in the following terms In exercise of the powers companyferred by Sub-section  1  of Section 4 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947  Orissa Act XIV of 1947  as applied to Orissa State, the Government of Orissa are pleased to appoint the 31st March, 1949, as the date

facts.text: Respondents assessed under Act for quarters ending September 30, 1949; December 31, 1949; June 30, 1950; September 30, 1950; December 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were assessed under the said Act for five quarters ending respectively on September 30, 1949, December 31, 1949, June 30, 1950, September 30, 1950, and December 31, 1950.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack assessed respondents; appeals dismissed April 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack having assessed the respondents to Sales Tax under the said Act for each and all of the said five quarters and the respondents several appeals against the said several assessment orders under the said Act having been dismissed on April 12, 1952,

facts.text: Respondents filed petition under Art.226 in Orissa HC for certiorari quashing assessments.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Orissa High Court praying, inter alia, for a writ in the nature of a writ of certiorari for quashing the said assessment orders

facts.text: Orissa High Court by judgment April 12, 1955 cancelled the assessments.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted both these companytentions and by its judgment and order pronounced on April 12, 1955, cancelled the assessments.

facts.text: Respondent is Messrs. B.C. Patel and Co., partnership firm carrying on business of collection and sale of Kendu leaves at Pallahara.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Messrs.B. C. Patel and Co., is a partnership firm carrying on the business of companylection and sale of Kendu leaves. The firm has its headquarters at Pallahara,

facts.text: Respondent collected Kendu leaves in Orissa and sold to merchants of Calcutta, Madras etc. on receipt of orders; goods sent f.o.r. Talcher or Calcutta; bills sent for payment; delivered for consumption outside Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which the Sales Tax authorities found were  I.  that the respondent companylected Kendu leaves in Orissa and sold them to various merchants of Calcutta, Madras and other places on receipt of orders from them,  2  that the goods were sent either f. o. r.

facts.text: Admitted that goods delivered for consumption outside State of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The admitted position was that the goods were delivered for companysumption at various places out- side the State of Orissa.

facts.text: Supreme Court held notification under s.4(1) valid only for appointing date March 31,1949; invalid for specifying wrong turnover year; severable.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the numberification, in so far as it appointed March 31, 1949, as the date with effect from which liability to pay tax would companymence was valid and the rest of the numberification was invalid

facts.text: It was conceded that respondents' gross turnover for period April 1,1949 to Jan 26,1950 exceeded Rs.5000 if valid notification.

anchor.surface_text: But a remand is number called for because it appears from the judgment under appeal that it was companyceded that for the period April 1, 1949, till the companymencement of the Constitution on January 26, 1950,

facts.text: Assessments for two pre-Constitution quarters valid under s.4(2).

anchor.surface_text: Even if we assume, companytrary to the aforesaid companycession, that the gross turnover of the respondents during the financial year ending on March 31, 1948, did number exceed Rs. 5,000 and, therefore, s. 4  1  did number apply to them the respondents will still be liable

facts.text: Assessments for three post-Constitution quarters invalid due to Art.286(1) and s.30(1)(a)(i).

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in companyplete agreement with  1  1953 S.C.R. 1069. our learned Brother S. K. Das J. for reasons stated by him that the assessment orders for the three post Constitution quarters were hit by cl.  1  of Art. 286

facts.text: Appeal allowed in part: pre-Constitution assessments valid, post invalid; parties bear own costs.

anchor.surface_text: We further hold that the assessments for the two pre-Constitution quarters were valid for reasons stated above and accordingly we agree in allowing this appeal in so far as it is against that part of the order

facts.text: S.K. Das J. held pre-Constitution assessments valid under s.4(2) as turnover exceeded Rs.5000 in year ending March 31,1949.

anchor.surface_text: What was found was that the respondents gross turnover exceeded Rs. 5,000 in 1948-49, that is, the year ending March 31,, 1949, which was number the year immediately preceding the companymencement of the Act

facts.text: Special leave granted January 17, 1956.

arguments.claim: The notification under s.4(1) dated March 1, 1949 is invalid because it specifies the wrong year for turnover (year ending March 31, 1949 instead of year preceding Act's commencement), running counter to s.4(1), so no part of charging section came into force and no liability for any quarters.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondents before the High Court was that the notification issued by the Government of Orissa on March 1, 1949, under s. 4 1  being invalid in that it ran counter to the provisions of that sub-section, no part of the charging section came into force and consequently they were not liable to tax at all for any of the five quarters.

arguments.claim: Mistake in notification immaterial; liability arises under s.4(1) not notification; erroneous words mere surplusage severable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General who has appeared for the appellants has conceded that a mistake was made in the notification. However, he has argued-firstly, that the mistake was immaterial and secondly, that the assessment orders for the pre-Constitution period were justified under sub-s. 2 of s 4. As to the first argument that the mistake was immaterial, he has submitted that the liability to tax arose under the sub-section and not under the notification, and any mistake in the notification did not affect such liability he has also submitted that the words and figures which gave rise to the mistake were mere surplusage and could be severed from the rest of the notification.

holdings.text: The notification under s.4(1) dated March 1, 1949 is valid insofar as it appoints March 31, 1949 as the date from which tax liability commences, but invalid insofar as it specifies the year ending March 31, 1949 for turnover threshold; the invalid part is severable.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the numberification, in so far as it appointed March 31, 1949, as the date with effect from which liability to pay tax would companymence was valid and the rest of the numberification was invalid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 4(1) empowers government only to appoint date; class of dealers determined by statute; invalid portion clearly severable as government would still appoint date if aware of limits.

holdings.text: Assessments for two pre-Constitution quarters valid as respondents' turnover exceeded Rs.5000 in year preceding appointed date per concession, bringing them under severed valid part of s.4(1).

holdings.text: Even assuming s.4(1) inapplicable, respondents liable under s.4(2) for pre-Constitution quarters as turnover first exceeded Rs.5000 in year after Act's commencement (1948-49).

holdings.text: Assessments for three post-Constitution quarters invalid as hit by Art.286(1) and s.30(1)(a)(i) since goods delivered for consumption outside Orissa.

holdings.text: Notification under s.4(1) wholly invalid as it incorrectly specifies relevant turnover period (year ending March 31, 1949 instead of preceding Act commencement); mistake not severable or immaterial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification essential prerequisite for s.4(1) liability; must conform to subsection specifying correct period; cannot sever as fixes both date and class wrongly.

holdings.text: Sub-sections 4(1) and 4(2) mutually exclusive only insofar as they operate in different fields/periods; s.4(2) applies independently where s.4(1) notification fails.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that they were not, and gave two reasons for its view one was that, subsections 1 and 2 were mutually exclusive and the other was based

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different relevant periods: s.4(1) uses year pre-Act; s.4(2) year of first excess post-Act; no notification needed for s.4(2); invalid s.4(1) notif does not bar s.4(2).

holdings.text: Pre-Constitution assessments valid under s.4(2) as gross turnover first exceeded Rs.5000 in 1948-49 (post-Act commencement in Pallahara), triggering liability from April 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Now, we come to the second argument whether the pre- Constitution assessment orders are justified under sub-s. 2 of s 4. The High Court held that they were not, and gave two

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show excess in 1948-49; 'first' after Act commencement; liability from next year start; fulfills all requirements despite invalid s.4(1) notif.

holdings.text: Sales Tax Continuance Order 1950 does not authorize tax on sales hit by Art.286(1)(a) (outside state sales); bans independent of cl.(2).

anchor.surface_text: for the post-Constitution period, though the sales came within cl.  2  of Art. 286 of the Constitution, the respondent was liable to sales tax under the Sales Tax Continuance Order, 1950, made by the President.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Bengal Immunity: cl.1(a) ban independent; President's order under cl.2 proviso does not override cl.1; Explanation applies to deem outside sales.

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in The State of Bombay v. The United Motors India Ltd. 1 Said the High Court Clause  1  of Article 286 prohibited a State from taxing a sale unless such sale took place within the State as explained in the Explanation to the clause of the Article.

anchor.surface_text: the Election Tribunal has numberpower to grant such an amendment, be it by way of withdrawal or abandonment of a part of the claim or otherwise, once, an Election Petition has been presented to the Election  companymission claiming such further declaration. Considering Civil Appeal No. 763 of 1957 in the light of the observations made above, we find that sundararaja Pillai whose name was included in the list of companytesting candidates prepared and published by the returning officer under s. 38 but who retired from the companytest under s. 55A  2  before the companymencement of the poll was included in the expression companytesting candidate used in s. 82 and was by reason of the first respondent claiming a further declaration that the second respondent had been duly elected, a necessary party to the petition. Inasmuch as he was number joined as a respondent, the petition was liable to be dismissed under s. 90 3  of the Act. This defect companyld number be cured by any amendment of the petition seeking to delete the claim for such further declaration and the Election Tribunal was clearly in error in allowing such amendment on the grounds disclosed in 1. A. No. 3 of 1957 or otherwise. In regard to the deposit of security, however, the position was quite different. According to the evidence given by K. Nataraja Mudaliar, head accountant in. charge of the Madurai Taluk sub-Treasury, the amount was kept in the Election Revenue deposit and the monies were at the disposal of the Election Commission also that the Election Commission or anyone Basappa v. Ayyappa, see p. 6ii, post. authorised by the Election Commission in that behalf companyld draw the said monies and numberone else companyld withdraw the same without such authority.
